name: Urinary & Genitourinary Infections
description: UTI, pyelonephritis, prostatitis, and GU infections

conditions.name: Uncomplicated Cystitis
conditions.shortDescription: Acute bacterial infection of the bladder in non-pregnant women without structural/functional urinary tract abnormalities

content.clinical_presentation: Dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, suprapubic pain. No fever or flank pain (suggests pyelonephritis).
content.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical symptoms + pyuria (≥10 WBC/hpf) or positive urine culture (≥10³ CFU/mL).

content.when_to_test: Urinalysis (UA) recommended. Urine culture NOT routinely needed for uncomplicated cystitis in non-pregnant women.
content.when_not_to_test: Do NOT culture asymptomatic bacteriuria (except in pregnancy or before urologic procedures)
essential_tests: Urine culture (if recurrent UTI, treatment failure, or atypical presentation)
conditional_tests: Urine culture: If pregnant, male, recurrent UTI, or recent antibiotic use
Renal function tests: If concern for pyelonephritis or AKI
content.specimen_collection: Clean-catch midstream urine. Avoid catheterization unless necessary.

content.resistance_patterns: E. coli resistance to ampicillin: 30-50%. TMP-SMX resistance: 15-25% in many regions. Fluoroquinolone resistance: 10-20%.

first_line.preferred: Nitrofurantoin 100mg PO BID x 5 days OR Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole DS PO BID x 3 days (if local resistance <20%)

content.alternatives: Beta-lactam allergy: Nitrofurantoin or fosfomycin. If TMP-SMX resistance >20%: Use nitrofurantoin or fosfomycin.
content.avoid_list: Avoid fluoroquinolones for uncomplicated cystitis (reserve for complicated UTI/pyelonephritis)

content.de_escalation: Switch to narrow-spectrum agent based on culture results
content.iv_to_po_switch: Not applicable (oral therapy for uncomplicated cystitis)

content.short_course: TMP-SMX: 3 days. Nitrofurantoin: 5 days. Fosfomycin: Single dose.
content.prolonged: 7 days if slow response or risk factors for complicated UTI

content.renal_dose: Avoid nitrofurantoin if CrCl <30 mL/min. Adjust TMP-SMX for CrCl <30 mL/min.
content.pregnancy: Preferred: Amoxicillin-clavulanate, cephalexin, nitrofurantoin (avoid in 3rd trimester). Avoid: TMP-SMX (1st trimester), fluoroquinolones.
content.recurrent_uti: Consider prophylaxis (nitrofurantoin 50-100mg daily, TMP-SMX SS daily, or post-coital dosing)

content.avoid_unnecessary_cultures: Do NOT culture asymptomatic bacteriuria (except pregnancy or pre-procedure)
timeout_checklist: Reassess at 48-72 hours if symptoms not improving
Review culture results if obtained
Avoid prolonged therapy (>5-7 days) unless complicated
content.iv_to_po_opportunities: Not applicable (oral therapy for uncomplicated cystitis)

conditions.name: Acute Pyelonephritis
conditions.shortDescription: Acute bacterial infection of the renal parenchyma and collecting system

content.clinical_presentation: Fever, chills, flank pain, costovertebral angle tenderness, nausea/vomiting. May have dysuria and urinary frequency.
content.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical symptoms + pyuria + positive urine culture (≥10⁴ CFU/mL).

content.when_to_test: All patients: Urine culture before antibiotics. Blood cultures if hospitalized or severe.
conditional_tests: CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast (if concern for abscess, obstruction, or emphysematous pyelonephritis)
Renal ultrasound (if CT contraindicated)
content.turnaround_time: Urine culture: 24-48 hours. Blood cultures: 24-48 hours. CT: Same day.

content.resistance_patterns: Similar to cystitis but higher rates of ESBL and fluoroquinolone resistance in hospitalized patients

first_line.outpatient_mild: Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO BID OR Levofloxacin 750mg PO daily (if local resistance <10%)
first_line.hospitalized_moderate: Ceftriaxone 1-2g IV daily OR Cefepime 1-2g IV q8-12h
first_line.severe_septic: Piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375g IV q6h OR Meropenem 1g IV q8h (if ESBL risk)

content.alternatives: Fluoroquinolone allergy: Ceftriaxone or cefepime. ESBL risk: Meropenem or ertapenem.
content.avoid_list: Avoid nitrofurantoin (does not achieve adequate tissue levels for pyelonephritis)

pathogen_specific.E_coli_susceptible: Ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, or ceftriaxone (based on susceptibility)
pathogen_specific.ESBL_E_coli: Meropenem 1g IV q8h OR Ertapenem 1g IV daily
pathogen_specific.Enterococcus: Ampicillin 2g IV q6h (if susceptible) OR Vancomycin (if VRE)

content.de_escalation: Switch to oral fluoroquinolone or TMP-SMX once afebrile and clinically stable
content.iv_to_po_switch: Criteria: Afebrile >24h, tolerating PO, clinically stable, pathogen susceptible to oral agent

content.short_course: 7 days if uncomplicated and good response
content.prolonged: 14 days if bacteremia, delayed response, or complications

content.renal_dose: Adjust fluoroquinolones, beta-lactams for CrCl <30 mL/min
content.pregnancy: Preferred: Ceftriaxone, cefepime. Avoid: Fluoroquinolones. Hospitalize all pregnant women with pyelonephritis.
content.obstruction: Urgent urology consult for drainage (nephrostomy or stent) if obstructive uropathy

timeout_checklist: Review culture results at 48-72 hours
De-escalate to narrow-spectrum oral agent
Switch IV to PO when clinically stable
Reassess duration (avoid >14 days unless complicated)
content.iv_to_po_opportunities: Most patients can switch to PO by day 2-3 if afebrile and stable

conditions.name: Complicated UTI
conditions.shortDescription: UTI in patients with structural/functional urinary tract abnormalities, immunosuppression, or healthcare-associated factors

content.definition: UTI occurring in patients with factors that increase risk of treatment failure: structural/functional urinary tract abnormalities, immunosuppression, male sex, pregnancy, indwelling catheter, recent instrumentation, or healthcare-associated acquisition.
content.clinical_presentation: Variable: May present like uncomplicated cystitis or pyelonephritis, but with higher risk of complications, bacteremia, and treatment failure. Symptoms: Dysuria, frequency, urgency, fever, flank pain.
content.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical symptoms + pyuria + positive urine culture (≥10⁴ CFU/mL). Consider imaging if concern for obstruction or abscess.

content.when_to_test: ALWAYS obtain urine culture before antibiotics in complicated UTI. Blood cultures if hospitalized or severe.
essential_tests: Blood cultures (2 sets) if hospitalized or severe
conditional_tests: CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast: If concern for obstruction, abscess, emphysematous pyelonephritis, or no improvement in 72h
Renal ultrasound: If CT contraindicated or to assess for hydronephrosis
Post-void residual: If concern for urinary retention
content.specimen_collection: Midstream clean-catch preferred. If catheterized, obtain fresh specimen (not from bag).
content.turnaround_time: Urine culture: 24-48 hours. Blood cultures: 24-48 hours. CT: Same day if urgent.

content.resistance_patterns: Higher rates of ESBL (15-30%), fluoroquinolone resistance (20-40%), and multidrug resistance compared to uncomplicated UTI. Pseudomonas often resistant to fluoroquinolones and cephalosporins.

first_line.mild_outpatient: Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO BID OR Levofloxacin 750mg PO daily (if local resistance <10% and no recent fluoroquinolone use)
first_line.moderate_hospitalized: Ceftriaxone 1-2g IV daily OR Cefepime 2g IV q8-12h
first_line.severe_or_ESBL_risk: Meropenem 1g IV q8h OR Ertapenem 1g IV daily OR Piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375g IV q6h (if Pseudomonas risk)

content.alternatives: Beta-lactam allergy: Aztreonam 1-2g IV q8h + vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h (for Gram-positive coverage). Fluoroquinolone allergy: Ceftriaxone or cefepime.
content.avoid_list: Avoid nitrofurantoin (inadequate tissue levels for complicated UTI). Avoid fosfomycin (not FDA-approved for complicated UTI).
content.pseudomonas_coverage: If risk factors (catheter, recent instrumentation, prior Pseudomonas): Use cefepime, piperacillin-tazobactam, or meropenem.

pathogen_specific.E_coli_susceptible: Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO BID OR Levofloxacin 750mg PO daily OR Ceftriaxone 1g IV daily
pathogen_specific.ESBL_producing: Meropenem 1g IV q8h OR Ertapenem 1g IV daily (preferred for ESBL)
pathogen_specific.Pseudomonas_aeruginosa: Cefepime 2g IV q8h OR Piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375g IV q6h OR Meropenem 1g IV q8h (based on susceptibility)
pathogen_specific.Enterococcus: Ampicillin 2g IV q6h (if susceptible) OR Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h (if VRE or ampicillin-resistant)
pathogen_specific.Candida: Fluconazole 400mg PO/IV daily (if susceptible) OR Micafungin 100mg IV daily (if azole-resistant)

content.de_escalation: Switch to narrow-spectrum agent based on culture results. Avoid prolonged broad-spectrum therapy.
content.iv_to_po_switch: Criteria: Afebrile >24-48h, tolerating PO, clinically stable, pathogen susceptible to oral agent with good bioavailability.

content.short_course: 7 days if uncomplicated course and good response
content.prolonged: 14 days if bacteremia, delayed response, obstruction, abscess, or immunosuppression. Consider 21 days for renal abscess or emphysematous pyelonephritis.

content.renal_dose: Adjust all antibiotics for CrCl <30 mL/min. Avoid nitrofurantoin if CrCl <30 mL/min.
content.immunosuppression: Longer duration (14 days). Consider fungal coverage if prolonged catheter or recent broad-spectrum antibiotics. Consult ID if transplant recipient.
content.obstruction: URGENT urology consult for drainage (nephrostomy, stent, or Foley). Antibiotics alone will fail without source control.
content.catheter_management: Remove or replace catheter if possible. Do NOT treat asymptomatic bacteriuria in catheterized patients unless pre-procedure.
content.male_patients: All UTIs in men are considered complicated. Rule out prostatitis (tender prostate on exam, elevated PSA).

timeout_checklist: Review culture results at 48-72 hours and de-escalate
Switch IV to PO when clinically stable (usually day 2-4)
Reassess duration: Avoid >14 days unless abscess or bacteremia
Remove or replace catheter if possible
Imaging if no improvement in 72 hours
content.iv_to_po_opportunities: Most patients can switch to PO by day 2-4 if afebrile and stable. Oral options: Ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, TMP-SMX (if susceptible).
content.avoid_unnecessary_treatment: Do NOT treat asymptomatic bacteriuria (except pregnancy or pre-urologic procedure). Do NOT treat catheter colonization without symptoms.

conditions.name: Recurrent UTI
conditions.shortDescription: ≥2 UTIs in 6 months or ≥3 UTIs in 12 months in women

content.definition: Recurrent UTI (rUTI) defined as ≥2 UTIs in 6 months OR ≥3 UTIs in 12 months. Most are reinfections (new infection with different organism) rather than relapse (same organism).
content.clinical_presentation: Typical cystitis symptoms: Dysuria, frequency, urgency, suprapubic pain. Recurrent episodes with similar symptoms. May have identifiable triggers (sexual activity, spermicide use, menopause).
content.diagnostic_criteria: History of documented recurrent UTIs + current symptoms + pyuria or positive urine culture.

content.when_to_test: Urine culture recommended for each episode to document infection and guide therapy. Consider urologic evaluation if ≥3 UTIs/year or risk factors for complications.
essential_tests: Urine culture with susceptibilities (for each episode)
Post-void residual (PVR) if concern for incomplete emptying
conditional_tests: Renal ultrasound: If concern for structural abnormality or stones
Cystoscopy: If hematuria, age >50, or concern for bladder pathology
Urodynamic studies: If urinary retention or neurogenic bladder suspected
Vaginal exam: If postmenopausal (assess for atrophic vaginitis)
content.when_not_to_test: Do NOT culture asymptomatic bacteriuria between episodes. Do NOT perform routine imaging in young women with typical rUTI.

content.resistance_patterns: May have higher resistance rates due to repeated antibiotic exposure. TMP-SMX resistance: 20-30%. Fluoroquinolone resistance: 15-25%. Consider local antibiogram.

first_line.acute_episode: Nitrofurantoin 100mg PO BID x 5 days OR TMP-SMX DS PO BID x 3 days (if local resistance <20% and no recent use)
first_line.alternative: Fosfomycin 3g PO single dose OR Cephalexin 500mg PO QID x 5-7 days

content.alternatives: If recent antibiotic use or known resistance: Base on prior culture results. Consider rotating antibiotic classes.
content.avoid_list: Avoid fluoroquinolones for uncomplicated rUTI (reserve for complicated UTI/pyelonephritis). Avoid same antibiotic used in previous episode if <3 months.

pathogen_specific.E_coli_susceptible: Continue empiric therapy if susceptible. Consider rotating antibiotic classes for future episodes.
pathogen_specific.multidrug_resistant: Base on susceptibility testing. May require fluoroquinolone or beta-lactam if resistant to first-line agents.
pathogen_specific.ESBL_producing: Nitrofurantoin (if susceptible) OR Fosfomycin OR Ertapenem 1g IV daily x 3-5 days (if severe)

content.de_escalation: Switch to narrow-spectrum agent based on culture results.
content.iv_to_po_switch: Not applicable (oral therapy for uncomplicated rUTI)

content.standard: 3-7 days for acute episodes (same as uncomplicated cystitis)
content.prolonged: Nitrofurantoin: 5-7 days. Consider 7 days if slow response.

content.prophylaxis_indications: Consider prophylaxis if ≥2 UTIs in 6 months or ≥3 UTIs in 12 months AND significantly impacting quality of life.

prophylaxis_options.continuous: Nitrofurantoin 50-100mg PO daily OR TMP-SMX SS (half-strength) PO daily OR Cephalexin 250mg PO daily. Duration: 6-12 months, then reassess.
prophylaxis_options.post_coital: Nitrofurantoin 50-100mg PO OR TMP-SMX SS PO OR Cephalexin 250mg PO within 2 hours after intercourse (if UTIs related to sexual activity)
prophylaxis_options.self_start_therapy: Patient-initiated therapy at first symptom (for reliable patients with typical symptoms)

non_antibiotic_prevention: Methenamine hippurate 1g PO BID (if urine pH <6)
content.postmenopausal_women: Vaginal estrogen therapy (estriol cream or ring) reduces rUTI by 50-75%. Preferred over antibiotic prophylaxis in postmenopausal women.

timeout_checklist: Reassess need for prophylaxis after 6-12 months
Encourage non-antibiotic prevention strategies
Avoid prolonged antibiotic prophylaxis (>12 months) without reassessment
Consider vaginal estrogen in postmenopausal women before antibiotic prophylaxis
content.avoid_unnecessary_treatment: Do NOT treat asymptomatic bacteriuria between episodes. Do NOT use prophylaxis for <2 UTIs in 6 months.
content.patient_education: Educate on behavioral modifications: Hydration, post-coital voiding, avoid spermicides, cranberry products, vaginal estrogen (if postmenopausal).

references.label: Cochrane Review: Cranberry for Preventing UTIs (2023)

conditions.name: Catheter-Associated UTI (CAUTI)
conditions.shortDescription: Symptomatic UTI in patient with indwelling urinary catheter or catheter removed within 48 hours

content.definition: CAUTI is a UTI occurring in a patient with an indwelling urinary catheter (Foley, suprapubic, or intermittent catheterization) OR within 48 hours of catheter removal, with symptoms attributable to the UTI.
content.clinical_presentation: Fever (>38°C), suprapubic tenderness, costovertebral angle tenderness, altered mental status (especially elderly), rigors, or new-onset delirium. NOTE: Cloudy or foul-smelling urine alone is NOT sufficient for diagnosis.
content.diagnostic_criteria: Indwelling catheter (or removed <48h) + symptoms (fever, suprapubic pain, CVA tenderness, delirium) + pyuria (≥10 WBC/hpf) + positive urine culture (≥10³ CFU/mL of ≥1 bacterial species).
content.do_not_treat: Asymptomatic bacteriuria (catheter colonization) - Do NOT treat unless patient is undergoing urologic procedure or is pregnant.

content.when_to_test: ONLY test if patient has symptoms. Do NOT screen for asymptomatic bacteriuria in catheterized patients.
essential_tests: Urinalysis (from fresh catheter specimen, NOT from bag)
Urine culture with susceptibilities (MANDATORY before antibiotics)
Blood cultures (2 sets) if fever or severe
conditional_tests: CT abdomen/pelvis: If no improvement in 72h or concern for abscess/obstruction
Renal ultrasound: If CT contraindicated
content.specimen_collection: Obtain urine from catheter port (NOT from drainage bag). If long-term catheter, consider replacing catheter before obtaining specimen.
content.turnaround_time: Urine culture: 24-48 hours. Blood cultures: 24-48 hours.
content.interpretation: Pyuria is ALWAYS present with catheter. Positive culture alone (without symptoms) = colonization, NOT infection.

likely_pathogens: Escherichia coli (30-50%, lower than community UTI)
Candida spp. (5-10%, especially if prolonged catheter or antibiotics)
content.polymicrobial: 30-40% of CAUTI are polymicrobial. Treat all significant pathogens.
content.resistance_patterns: High rates of multidrug resistance: ESBL (20-30%), fluoroquinolone resistance (30-50%), VRE (10-20%). Pseudomonas often resistant to fluoroquinolones and cephalosporins.
mdro_risk_factors: Recent hospitalization or nursing home residence

first_line.mild_moderate: Ceftriaxone 1-2g IV daily OR Cefepime 2g IV q8-12h (covers Pseudomonas)
first_line.severe_or_MDRO_risk: Piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375g IV q6h OR Meropenem 1g IV q8h (if ESBL risk or recent carbapenem-resistant organism)

content.enterococcal_coverage: Add vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h if risk factors for VRE (prolonged hospitalization, prior VRE, ICU) OR if Gram-positive cocci in urine Gram stain.
content.alternatives: Beta-lactam allergy: Aztreonam 1-2g IV q8h (Gram-negative) + vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h (Gram-positive).
content.avoid_list: Avoid nitrofurantoin (inadequate tissue levels). Avoid fosfomycin (not FDA-approved for CAUTI). Avoid fluoroquinolones as empiric therapy (high resistance rates).
content.candida_coverage: If Candida in urine culture + symptoms + no other pathogen: Fluconazole 400mg PO/IV daily (if susceptible) OR Micafungin 100mg IV daily (if azole-resistant or critically ill).

pathogen_specific.E_coli_susceptible: Ceftriaxone 1g IV daily OR Ciprofloxacin 400mg IV q12h (if susceptible)
pathogen_specific.ESBL_producing: Meropenem 1g IV q8h OR Ertapenem 1g IV daily
pathogen_specific.Pseudomonas_aeruginosa: Cefepime 2g IV q8h OR Piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375g IV q6h OR Meropenem 1g IV q8h (based on susceptibility)
pathogen_specific.VRE: Linezolid 600mg PO/IV q12h OR Daptomycin 6mg/kg IV daily
pathogen_specific.Candida: Fluconazole 400mg PO/IV daily (if susceptible) OR Micafungin 100mg IV daily

content.de_escalation: Switch to narrow-spectrum agent based on culture results. Discontinue vancomycin if no VRE.
content.iv_to_po_switch: Criteria: Afebrile >24-48h, tolerating PO, clinically stable, pathogen susceptible to oral agent. Options: Ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, TMP-SMX, fluconazole (for Candida).

content.standard: 7 days if prompt resolution and catheter removed
content.short_course: 5-7 days if catheter removed and good response
content.prolonged: 10-14 days if catheter remains in place, delayed response, or bacteremia. Consider 14 days for Pseudomonas or Candida.

content.catheter_management: REMOVE or REPLACE catheter as soon as possible. Antibiotics alone (without catheter removal) have higher failure rates. If catheter must remain, replace it before starting antibiotics.
content.source_control: Catheter removal is the most important intervention. Consider alternatives: Intermittent catheterization, condom catheter (men), or bladder training.
content.renal_dose: Adjust all antibiotics for CrCl <30 mL/min.
content.immunosuppression: Longer duration (10-14 days). Consider fungal coverage if prolonged catheter or recent broad-spectrum antibiotics.
content.spinal_cord_injury: Higher risk of CAUTI. Consider intermittent catheterization instead of indwelling catheter. Do NOT treat asymptomatic bacteriuria.

timeout_checklist: Review culture results at 48-72 hours and de-escalate
REMOVE catheter if no longer needed (most important intervention)
Switch IV to PO when clinically stable (usually day 2-4)
Reassess duration: 7 days if catheter removed, 10-14 days if remains
Discontinue vancomycin if no VRE
content.iv_to_po_opportunities: Most patients can switch to PO by day 2-4 if afebrile and stable. Oral options: Ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, TMP-SMX (if susceptible).
content.avoid_unnecessary_treatment: Do NOT treat asymptomatic bacteriuria (catheter colonization). Do NOT culture urine without symptoms. Do NOT use prophylactic antibiotics in catheterized patients.
prevention: Use catheters only when necessary (avoid for incontinence or convenience)
Remove catheters as soon as possible
Consider alternatives: Intermittent catheterization, condom catheter

conditions.name: Acute Bacterial Prostatitis
conditions.shortDescription: Acute bacterial infection of the prostate gland in men

content.definition: Acute bacterial prostatitis (ABP) is an acute infection of the prostate gland, typically presenting with fever, pelvic pain, and urinary symptoms. Can progress to sepsis if untreated.
content.clinical_presentation: Fever, chills, dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency, perineal or suprapubic pain, low back pain, myalgias. May have urinary retention. Digital rectal exam (DRE): Tender, boggy, swollen prostate (AVOID vigorous exam - risk of bacteremia).
content.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical symptoms + tender prostate on DRE + pyuria + positive urine culture. Elevated PSA (not diagnostic, returns to baseline after treatment).
red_flags: Prostatic abscess (suspect if persistent fever >72h despite antibiotics)

content.when_to_test: All patients: Urine culture before antibiotics. Blood cultures if hospitalized or severe. AVOID vigorous prostate massage (risk of bacteremia).
essential_tests: Blood cultures (2 sets) if fever or severe
PSA (elevated in acute phase, recheck after treatment)
conditional_tests: Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) or CT pelvis: If concern for prostatic abscess (persistent fever >72h)
Post-void residual: If concern for urinary retention
STI testing (gonorrhea, chlamydia): If age <35 or sexually active
content.specimen_collection: Midstream urine (pre-massage). AVOID vigorous prostate massage in acute phase.
content.turnaround_time: Urine culture: 24-48 hours. Blood cultures: 24-48 hours. Imaging: Same day if abscess suspected.

likely_pathogens: Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis (if age <35 or STI risk)
content.resistance_patterns: Similar to complicated UTI. Fluoroquinolone resistance: 15-25%. ESBL: 10-20% (higher if healthcare-associated).

first_line.outpatient_mild: Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO BID OR Levofloxacin 750mg PO daily (fluoroquinolones have excellent prostate penetration)
first_line.hospitalized_moderate: Ceftriaxone 1-2g IV daily + Doxycycline 100mg PO/IV BID (if STI risk) OR Ciprofloxacin 400mg IV q12h
first_line.severe_septic: Piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375g IV q6h OR Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily + Gentamicin 5-7mg/kg IV daily

content.sti_coverage: If age <35 or sexually active: Add doxycycline 100mg PO BID OR ceftriaxone 500mg IM single dose (for gonorrhea).
content.alternatives: Fluoroquinolone allergy: TMP-SMX DS PO BID (good prostate penetration) OR Doxycycline 100mg PO BID.
content.avoid_list: Avoid nitrofurantoin (poor prostate penetration). Avoid fosfomycin (inadequate prostate levels).

pathogen_specific.E_coli_susceptible: Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO BID OR Levofloxacin 750mg PO daily OR TMP-SMX DS PO BID (if susceptible)
pathogen_specific.ESBL_producing: Meropenem 1g IV q8h OR Ertapenem 1g IV daily (then switch to PO if susceptible to ciprofloxacin or TMP-SMX)
pathogen_specific.Pseudomonas_aeruginosa: Ciprofloxacin 400mg IV q12h OR Cefepime 2g IV q8h (based on susceptibility)
pathogen_specific.Enterococcus: Ampicillin 2g IV q6h (if susceptible) OR Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h (if VRE)
pathogen_specific.Gonorrhea: Ceftriaxone 500mg IM single dose + Doxycycline 100mg PO BID x 10 days

content.de_escalation: Switch to oral fluoroquinolone or TMP-SMX once afebrile and clinically stable.
content.iv_to_po_switch: Criteria: Afebrile >24-48h, tolerating PO, clinically stable, pathogen susceptible to oral agent with good prostate penetration.

content.standard: 4-6 weeks total (IV + PO) - Prolonged duration needed for prostate penetration and eradication
content.short_course: 4 weeks if uncomplicated and good response
content.prolonged: 6 weeks if bacteremia, delayed response, or prostatic abscess. Consider 8-12 weeks if abscess drained.

content.urinary_retention: If acute urinary retention: Place suprapubic catheter (preferred) OR Foley catheter. Avoid urethral catheterization if possible (risk of bacteremia).
content.prostatic_abscess: Suspect if persistent fever >72h despite antibiotics. Diagnosis: TRUS or CT pelvis. Treatment: Drainage (TRUS-guided aspiration or TURP) + prolonged antibiotics (6-8 weeks).
content.renal_dose: Adjust fluoroquinolones, TMP-SMX for CrCl <30 mL/min.
content.sti_risk: If age <35 or sexually active: Test for gonorrhea and chlamydia. Treat empirically if high suspicion.
content.recurrence: If recurrent ABP: Consider chronic bacterial prostatitis. Longer duration (6-12 weeks) and urologic evaluation.

timeout_checklist: Review culture results at 48-72 hours and de-escalate
Switch IV to PO when clinically stable (usually day 2-4)
Ensure total duration is 4-6 weeks (prostate penetration requires prolonged therapy)
Imaging if no improvement in 72 hours (rule out abscess)
Recheck PSA after treatment (should normalize)
content.iv_to_po_opportunities: Most patients can switch to PO by day 2-4 if afebrile and stable. Oral options: Ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, TMP-SMX (if susceptible).
content.avoid_unnecessary_treatment: Do NOT treat asymptomatic bacteriuria. Do NOT use short-course therapy (<4 weeks) - high relapse rate.

conditions.name: Chronic Bacterial Prostatitis
conditions.shortDescription: Chronic or recurrent bacterial infection of the prostate gland

content.definition: Chronic bacterial prostatitis (CBP) is a recurrent or persistent bacterial infection of the prostate, characterized by recurrent UTIs with the same organism. Accounts for 5-10% of chronic prostatitis cases.
content.clinical_presentation: Recurrent UTIs (same organism), pelvic/perineal pain, dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency, low back pain, post-ejaculatory pain. Symptoms are typically less severe than acute prostatitis. DRE: May be normal or show mild tenderness.
content.diagnostic_criteria: Recurrent UTIs with same organism + positive post-prostate massage urine culture (≥10-fold higher CFU than pre-massage urine). Symptoms >3 months.
differential_diagnosis: Chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CPPS) - Most common (90-95% of chronic prostatitis)

content.when_to_test: Obtain urine culture before and after prostate massage (Meares-Stamey 4-glass test or simplified 2-glass test). Culture during symptomatic episodes.
essential_tests: Post-prostate massage urine culture (VB3 or expressed prostatic secretions)
PSA (may be elevated, recheck after treatment)
conditional_tests: Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS): If concern for prostatic calculi or abscess
Cystoscopy: If hematuria or concern for bladder pathology
Urodynamic studies: If voiding dysfunction
STI testing: If age <35 or sexually active
content.meares_stamey_test: 4-glass test: VB1 (first 10mL urine), VB2 (midstream urine), EPS (expressed prostatic secretions after massage), VB3 (first 10mL urine after massage). CBP: VB3 or EPS has ≥10-fold higher CFU than VB1/VB2.

content.resistance_patterns: Higher resistance rates due to repeated antibiotic exposure. Fluoroquinolone resistance: 20-30%. TMP-SMX resistance: 15-25%.
content.biofilm_formation: Bacteria in prostate may form biofilms, making eradication difficult. Prostatic calculi can harbor bacteria.

first_line.preferred: Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO BID OR Levofloxacin 750mg PO daily (fluoroquinolones have excellent prostate penetration)
first_line.alternative: TMP-SMX DS PO BID (if local resistance <20% and no recent use)

content.alternatives: Doxycycline 100mg PO BID (if fluoroquinolone allergy or resistance). Azithromycin 500mg PO daily (if intolerant to other agents).
content.avoid_list: Avoid nitrofurantoin (poor prostate penetration). Avoid fosfomycin (inadequate prostate levels). Avoid beta-lactams (poor prostate penetration except in acute inflammation).

pathogen_specific.E_coli_susceptible: Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO BID OR Levofloxacin 750mg PO daily OR TMP-SMX DS PO BID (if susceptible)
pathogen_specific.fluoroquinolone_resistant: TMP-SMX DS PO BID (if susceptible) OR Doxycycline 100mg PO BID
pathogen_specific.ESBL_producing: Difficult to treat. Consider prolonged course of ciprofloxacin or TMP-SMX if susceptible. May require IV ertapenem 1g daily x 2-4 weeks then PO suppression.
pathogen_specific.Enterococcus: Amoxicillin 500mg PO TID OR Doxycycline 100mg PO BID
pathogen_specific.Pseudomonas: Ciprofloxacin 500-750mg PO BID (if susceptible). May require IV therapy initially.

content.de_escalation: Switch to narrow-spectrum agent based on culture results.
content.iv_to_po_switch: Rarely need IV therapy for CBP (unlike acute prostatitis). Use PO agents with good prostate penetration.

content.standard: 6-12 weeks (prolonged duration needed for prostate penetration and biofilm eradication)
content.short_course: 6 weeks minimum (shorter courses have high relapse rates)
content.prolonged: 12 weeks if recurrent or persistent symptoms. Some patients may require suppressive therapy (low-dose daily antibiotics) if recurrent despite adequate treatment.
content.suppressive_therapy: If ≥3 relapses despite adequate treatment: Consider long-term suppressive therapy with ciprofloxacin 250mg PO daily OR TMP-SMX SS PO daily. Reassess every 6-12 months.

content.renal_dose: Adjust fluoroquinolones, TMP-SMX for CrCl <30 mL/min.
content.prostatic_calculi: Prostatic stones can harbor bacteria and prevent eradication. Consider TURP if recurrent despite adequate antibiotics.
content.alpha_blockers: Consider adding alpha-blocker (tamsulosin 0.4mg PO daily) to improve urinary symptoms and prostate drainage. May improve antibiotic penetration.
content.nsaids: NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen) may help with pelvic pain and inflammation.
content.pelvic_floor_therapy: Consider pelvic floor physical therapy if chronic pelvic pain persists despite antibiotics (may have CPPS component).
content.surgical_options: TURP (transurethral resection of prostate) may be considered if recurrent despite medical therapy, especially if prostatic calculi present.

timeout_checklist: Review culture results and de-escalate to narrow-spectrum agent
Ensure adequate duration (6-12 weeks minimum)
Reassess at 6 weeks: If symptoms persist, consider longer course or urologic evaluation
Avoid repeated short courses (<6 weeks) - high relapse rate
Consider suppressive therapy only if ≥3 relapses despite adequate treatment
content.avoid_unnecessary_treatment: Do NOT treat asymptomatic bacteriuria. Do NOT use short-course therapy (<6 weeks). Distinguish CBP from chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CPPS) - CPPS does NOT require antibiotics.
content.patient_education: Educate on prolonged treatment duration (6-12 weeks). Advise on symptom management (alpha-blockers, NSAIDs, pelvic floor therapy). Discuss risk of relapse and need for follow-up.

conditions.name: UTI in Pregnancy
conditions.shortDescription: Urinary tract infections during pregnancy, including asymptomatic bacteriuria, cystitis, and pyelonephritis

content.definition: UTI in pregnancy includes: (1) Asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB): ≥10⁵ CFU/mL without symptoms, (2) Acute cystitis: Symptomatic bladder infection, (3) Acute pyelonephritis: Upper tract infection with fever. Pregnancy increases risk of progression from ASB to pyelonephritis (20-40% if untreated).

clinical_presentation.asymptomatic_bacteriuria: NO symptoms. Detected on routine prenatal screening urine culture.
clinical_presentation.acute_cystitis: Dysuria, frequency, urgency, suprapubic pain. NO fever or flank pain.
clinical_presentation.acute_pyelonephritis: Fever, chills, flank pain, nausea/vomiting, costovertebral angle tenderness. May have contractions or preterm labor.

content.diagnostic_criteria: ASB: ≥10⁵ CFU/mL on 2 consecutive cultures without symptoms. Cystitis: Symptoms + pyuria + positive culture. Pyelonephritis: Fever + flank pain + pyuria + positive culture.
red_flags: Acute respiratory distress (rare complication of pyelonephritis in pregnancy)
content.complications: Untreated ASB → pyelonephritis (20-40%), preterm birth, low birth weight, perinatal mortality. Pyelonephritis → preterm labor, sepsis, ARDS (rare).

content.when_to_test: SCREEN all pregnant women for ASB at first prenatal visit (12-16 weeks) with urine culture. Repeat if high risk. Test for symptomatic UTI anytime during pregnancy.
essential_tests: Urine culture with susceptibilities (MANDATORY for all pregnant women at first visit)
conditional_tests: Renal ultrasound: If pyelonephritis not improving in 72h or concern for obstruction
Fetal monitoring: If preterm labor or fetal distress
Repeat urine culture: 1-2 weeks after treatment (test of cure)
content.specimen_collection: Clean-catch midstream urine. Avoid catheterization unless necessary.
content.turnaround_time: Urine culture: 24-48 hours. Blood cultures: 24-48 hours.
content.screening_recommendation: USPSTF Grade A recommendation: Screen all pregnant women for ASB at 12-16 weeks gestation.

likely_pathogens: Group B Streptococcus (GBS) - Important in pregnancy
content.resistance_patterns: Similar to non-pregnant women. Ampicillin resistance: 30-50%. TMP-SMX resistance: 15-25%.
content.gbs_colonization: Group B Streptococcus (GBS) bacteriuria at any time during pregnancy = heavy colonization. Requires intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis (IAP) during labor.

asymptomatic_bacteriuria.first_line: Nitrofurantoin 100mg PO BID x 5-7 days (AVOID in 3rd trimester, especially >36 weeks) OR Amoxicillin-clavulanate 500mg PO TID x 5-7 days OR Cephalexin 500mg PO QID x 5-7 days

acute_cystitis.first_line: Nitrofurantoin 100mg PO BID x 5-7 days (AVOID in 3rd trimester) OR Amoxicillin-clavulanate 500mg PO TID x 5-7 days OR Cephalexin 500mg PO QID x 5-7 days

acute_pyelonephritis.hospitalized: Ceftriaxone 1-2g IV daily OR Cefepime 1-2g IV q8-12h OR Ampicillin 2g IV q6h + Gentamicin 5mg/kg IV daily (if severe)
acute_pyelonephritis.outpatient_mild: Ceftriaxone 1g IV daily x 1-2 days, then cephalexin 500mg PO QID (if improving and afebrile)

content.avoid_list: AVOID: Fluoroquinolones (teratogenic), TMP-SMX in 1st trimester (neural tube defects) and 3rd trimester (kernicterus), nitrofurantoin in 3rd trimester >36 weeks (hemolytic anemia in newborn), tetracyclines (bone/teeth effects).
content.safe_in_pregnancy: Safe: Penicillins, cephalosporins, fosfomycin, nitrofurantoin (except 3rd trimester), aztreonam.

pathogen_specific.E_coli_susceptible: Amoxicillin 500mg PO TID OR Cephalexin 500mg PO QID OR Nitrofurantoin 100mg PO BID (if <36 weeks)
pathogen_specific.ampicillin_resistant: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 500mg PO TID OR Cephalexin 500mg PO QID
pathogen_specific.ESBL_producing: Difficult in pregnancy. Consider IV ertapenem 1g daily (limited data but likely safe) OR prolonged ceftriaxone if susceptible.
pathogen_specific.Enterococcus: Ampicillin 500mg PO QID OR Amoxicillin 500mg PO TID
pathogen_specific.GBS: Ampicillin 500mg PO QID x 5-7 days. NOTE: GBS bacteriuria = heavy colonization, requires intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis (IAP) during labor.

content.de_escalation: Switch to narrow-spectrum agent based on culture results.
content.iv_to_po_switch: Criteria (pyelonephritis): Afebrile >24-48h, tolerating PO, no contractions, fetal well-being confirmed.

content.acute_pyelonephritis: 10-14 days total (IV + PO). Hospitalize all pregnant women with pyelonephritis.
content.test_of_cure: MANDATORY: Repeat urine culture 1-2 weeks after treatment completion. If positive, retreat and consider suppressive therapy.

content.hospitalization: HOSPITALIZE all pregnant women with pyelonephritis. Consider hospitalization for cystitis if unable to tolerate PO, dehydration, or preterm labor.
content.fetal_monitoring: Monitor fetal well-being if pyelonephritis or preterm labor. Consider tocolytics if contractions.
content.suppressive_therapy: If recurrent UTI (≥2 episodes) or persistent ASB after 2 treatment courses: Consider suppressive therapy with nitrofurantoin 50-100mg PO daily OR cephalexin 250mg PO daily until delivery (AVOID nitrofurantoin after 36 weeks).
content.gbs_management: If GBS bacteriuria detected: Treat with appropriate antibiotic + intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis (IAP) during labor (penicillin G 5 million units IV load, then 2.5-3 million units IV q4h until delivery).
content.postpartum: Reassess need for suppressive therapy postpartum. Most women do not need continued prophylaxis after delivery.
content.renal_dose: Adjust antibiotics for renal impairment (rare in pregnancy).

timeout_checklist: Review culture results and de-escalate to narrow-spectrum agent
Ensure test of cure (repeat urine culture 1-2 weeks after treatment)
Switch IV to PO when afebrile and stable (pyelonephritis)
Reassess need for suppressive therapy if recurrent
Document GBS bacteriuria for intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis
content.screening_compliance: Ensure all pregnant women screened for ASB at 12-16 weeks. Treat all ASB in pregnancy (unlike non-pregnant women).
content.avoid_teratogens: AVOID fluoroquinolones, tetracyclines, TMP-SMX in 1st/3rd trimester, nitrofurantoin >36 weeks.
content.patient_education: Educate on importance of completing full course, test of cure, and reporting symptoms promptly. Discuss safe antibiotics in pregnancy.

references.label: ACOG Practice Bulletin: UTI in Pregnancy (2020)
USPSTF Screening for ASB in Pregnancy (2019)

conditions.name: Asymptomatic Bacteriuria
conditions.shortDescription: Presence of bacteria in urine (≥10⁵ CFU/mL) without urinary symptoms - when to treat vs. not treat

content.definition: Asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) is the presence of ≥10⁵ CFU/mL of bacteria in urine WITHOUT symptoms of UTI (no dysuria, frequency, urgency, fever, or flank pain). Common in elderly, catheterized patients, and pregnant women.
content.clinical_presentation: NO symptoms. Detected incidentally on urine culture or urinalysis. Patient may have cloudy or foul-smelling urine, but this alone is NOT an indication for treatment.
content.prevalence: Elderly women: 10-20%. Elderly men: 5-10%. Nursing home residents: 25-50%. Catheterized patients: Nearly 100% if catheter >1 month. Pregnant women: 2-10%.
content.diagnostic_criteria: ≥10⁵ CFU/mL on 2 consecutive urine cultures (women) or 1 culture (men) WITHOUT urinary symptoms.
when_to_treat: Pregnancy (ALWAYS treat - prevents pyelonephritis and preterm birth)
Before urologic procedures with mucosal trauma (TURP, cystoscopy with biopsy, stone removal)
when_not_to_treat: Catheterized patients (except before catheter removal for urologic procedure)

content.when_to_test: Do NOT screen for ASB in most populations. ONLY screen in pregnancy (12-16 weeks) and before urologic procedures with mucosal trauma.
content.when_not_to_test: Do NOT obtain urine cultures in asymptomatic patients (elderly, catheterized, diabetics, nursing home residents). Do NOT test urine from catheter bags.
essential_tests: Urine culture with susceptibilities (if screening indicated: pregnancy or pre-procedure)
conditional_tests: Urinalysis: NOT recommended for ASB screening (pyuria is common and does NOT indicate need for treatment)
content.specimen_collection: Clean-catch midstream urine (women). Midstream urine (men). Fresh catheter specimen if catheterized (NOT from bag).
content.interpretation: Pyuria (WBCs in urine) is COMMON with ASB and does NOT indicate need for treatment. Positive urine culture without symptoms = ASB, NOT infection.

content.polymicrobial: Common in catheterized patients and elderly. Polymicrobial bacteriuria does NOT require treatment unless symptomatic.
content.resistance_patterns: Similar to symptomatic UTI. May have higher resistance rates in nursing home residents and catheterized patients.

pregnancy.first_line: Nitrofurantoin 100mg PO BID x 5-7 days (AVOID in 3rd trimester >36 weeks) OR Amoxicillin-clavulanate 500mg PO TID x 5-7 days OR Cephalexin 500mg PO QID x 5-7 days

pre_urologic_procedure.first_line: Base on urine culture susceptibilities. Treat 1-2 days before procedure. Options: Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO BID OR TMP-SMX DS PO BID OR Cephalexin 500mg PO QID (if susceptible)
pre_urologic_procedure.duration: 1-2 days before procedure, continue 1-3 days after (total 3-5 days)

kidney_transplant.first_line: Consult transplant ID. Typically: TMP-SMX DS PO BID OR Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO BID x 5-7 days (first 3-6 months post-transplant only)

content.do_not_treat: Do NOT treat ASB in non-pregnant women, men (except pre-procedure), elderly, diabetics, catheterized patients, or spinal cord injury patients.

pathogen_specific.E_coli_susceptible: Amoxicillin 500mg PO TID OR Cephalexin 500mg PO QID OR Nitrofurantoin 100mg PO BID (pregnancy) OR Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO BID (pre-procedure)
pathogen_specific.ESBL_producing: Difficult. Consider fosfomycin 3g PO single dose (pregnancy) OR IV ertapenem (if severe or pre-procedure)
pathogen_specific.Enterococcus: Ampicillin 500mg PO QID OR Amoxicillin 500mg PO TID
pathogen_specific.GBS_in_pregnancy: Ampicillin 500mg PO QID x 5-7 days. NOTE: GBS bacteriuria = heavy colonization, requires intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis (IAP) during labor.

content.de_escalation: Switch to narrow-spectrum agent based on culture results.

content.pregnancy: 5-7 days. Test of cure (repeat urine culture) 1-2 weeks after treatment.
content.pre_urologic_procedure: 3-5 days total (1-2 days before + 1-3 days after procedure)
content.do_not_treat: 0 days for all other populations (no treatment indicated)

content.elderly: Do NOT treat ASB in elderly (including nursing home residents). Treatment does NOT reduce morbidity, mortality, or symptomatic UTI. May increase antibiotic resistance and adverse effects.
content.catheterized_patients: Do NOT treat ASB in catheterized patients. Nearly all catheterized patients have bacteriuria. Treatment does NOT prevent symptomatic CAUTI. Remove catheter if no longer needed.
content.diabetics: Do NOT treat ASB in diabetics. No evidence of benefit. May increase resistance.
content.spinal_cord_injury: Do NOT treat ASB in spinal cord injury patients. Treatment does NOT prevent symptomatic UTI and increases resistance.
content.chronic_kidney_disease: Do NOT treat ASB in CKD patients. No evidence of benefit.
content.post_kidney_transplant: Treat ASB only in first 3-6 months post-transplant. After 6 months, do NOT treat ASB.
content.pre_procedure_screening: Screen for ASB before urologic procedures with mucosal trauma (TURP, cystoscopy with biopsy, stone removal). Do NOT screen before clean procedures (cystoscopy without biopsy, urodynamics).

timeout_checklist: Confirm patient has symptoms before treating 'UTI'
Do NOT treat ASB in non-pregnant, non-procedure patients
Do NOT obtain urine cultures in asymptomatic patients
Educate providers on when NOT to treat ASB
Remove catheters if no longer needed (instead of treating ASB)
content.avoid_unnecessary_treatment: ASB is one of the most common causes of inappropriate antibiotic use. Do NOT treat ASB except in pregnancy, pre-urologic procedure, or early post-transplant. Pyuria alone is NOT an indication for treatment.
content.patient_education: Educate patients that bacteria in urine without symptoms is common and does NOT require antibiotics (except pregnancy). Cloudy or foul-smelling urine alone is NOT an indication for treatment.
content.nursing_home_stewardship: Implement protocols to avoid urine testing in asymptomatic nursing home residents. Use McGeer criteria for diagnosing UTI in long-term care (requires symptoms + positive culture).

conditions.name: Renal & Perinephric Abscess
conditions.shortDescription: Localized collection of pus within the renal parenchyma (renal abscess) or in the space between kidney and Gerota's fascia (perinephric abscess)

content.definition: Renal abscess: Localized collection of pus within the renal parenchyma. Perinephric abscess: Collection of pus in the perinephric space (between kidney capsule and Gerota's fascia). Both are serious complications of pyelonephritis or hematogenous seeding.
content.clinical_presentation: Fever, chills, flank pain, costovertebral angle tenderness, malaise. Symptoms often persist >5-7 days despite antibiotics for pyelonephritis. May have palpable flank mass. Sepsis in 20-30%.
content.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical symptoms + imaging (CT or ultrasound) showing fluid collection with rim enhancement. Blood or urine cultures may be positive.
red_flags: Persistent fever >72 hours despite antibiotics for pyelonephritis

content.when_to_test: Suspect renal/perinephric abscess if pyelonephritis not improving after 72 hours of appropriate antibiotics. Obtain imaging (CT preferred).
essential_tests: CT abdomen/pelvis with IV contrast (GOLD STANDARD - shows abscess, size, location, gas)
CBC, CMP (assess renal function, WBC, glucose)
conditional_tests: Renal ultrasound: If CT contraindicated (pregnancy, contrast allergy). Less sensitive than CT.
Abscess aspiration/drainage: For culture and susceptibilities (especially if blood/urine cultures negative)
Chest X-ray: If concern for septic emboli (hematogenous seeding)
content.imaging_findings: CT: Hypodense fluid collection with rim enhancement. May see gas (emphysematous). Perinephric abscess extends beyond kidney capsule. Renal abscess confined to parenchyma.
content.turnaround_time: CT: Same day (urgent). Blood/urine cultures: 24-48 hours. Abscess culture: 24-48 hours.

hematogenous_seeding: Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA or MRSA) - Especially in IV drug users

content.polymicrobial: 20-30% of cases are polymicrobial, especially if perinephric abscess.
content.resistance_patterns: High rates of ESBL (20-30%) and fluoroquinolone resistance (30-40%). MRSA if hematogenous seeding.
content.anaerobes: Rare, but consider if gas-forming abscess or recent GI surgery.

first_line.ascending_infection: Piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375g IV q6h OR Meropenem 1g IV q8h (if ESBL risk or severe)
first_line.hematogenous_seeding: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h + Piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375g IV q6h (covers MRSA + Gram-negatives)
first_line.iv_drug_user: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h + Cefepime 2g IV q8h (covers MRSA + Pseudomonas)

content.alternatives: Beta-lactam allergy: Aztreonam 2g IV q8h + vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h.
content.avoid_list: Avoid oral antibiotics initially. Avoid nitrofurantoin (inadequate tissue levels). Avoid monotherapy (high failure rate).
content.source_control: Drainage is MANDATORY for abscesses >3-5cm or if no improvement in 48-72h despite antibiotics. Antibiotics alone have high failure rate.

pathogen_specific.E_coli_susceptible: Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily OR Ciprofloxacin 400mg IV q12h (if susceptible)
pathogen_specific.ESBL_producing: Meropenem 1g IV q8h OR Ertapenem 1g IV daily
pathogen_specific.Pseudomonas_aeruginosa: Cefepime 2g IV q8h OR Piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375g IV q6h OR Meropenem 1g IV q8h (based on susceptibility)
pathogen_specific.MSSA: Nafcillin 2g IV q4h OR Cefazolin 2g IV q8h
pathogen_specific.MRSA: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h OR Daptomycin 6-8mg/kg IV daily
pathogen_specific.Enterococcus: Ampicillin 2g IV q6h (if susceptible) OR Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h (if VRE)

content.de_escalation: Switch to narrow-spectrum agent based on culture results. Discontinue vancomycin if no MRSA.
content.iv_to_po_switch: Criteria: Afebrile >48-72h, abscess drained or resolving on imaging, tolerating PO, pathogen susceptible to oral agent with good bioavailability. Switch after 2-4 weeks of IV therapy.

content.standard: 4-6 weeks total (IV + PO) - Prolonged duration needed for abscess eradication
content.short_course: 4 weeks if abscess <3cm and drained, good response
content.prolonged: 6-8 weeks if abscess >5cm, delayed drainage, or slow response. Consider 8-12 weeks if perinephric abscess or immunosuppressed.
content.iv_duration: 2-4 weeks IV, then switch to PO if improving and abscess drained/resolving.

content.drainage_indications: MANDATORY drainage if: Abscess >3-5cm, no improvement in 48-72h despite antibiotics, gas-forming abscess, or septic shock. Options: Percutaneous drainage (CT or ultrasound-guided) OR surgical drainage (open or laparoscopic).
content.percutaneous_drainage: Preferred initial approach. CT or ultrasound-guided aspiration or catheter placement. Success rate: 70-90% if abscess <5cm.
content.surgical_drainage: Indicated if: Percutaneous drainage fails, abscess >10cm, multiloculated abscess, or need for nephrectomy (non-functioning kidney).
content.diabetes_management: Optimize glucose control (target <180mg/dL). Poor glycemic control associated with treatment failure.
content.obstruction: Urgent urology consult if obstructive uropathy (stone, stricture). Relieve obstruction (stent, nephrostomy) + drainage + antibiotics.
content.immunosuppression: Longer duration (6-8 weeks). Consider fungal coverage if prolonged broad-spectrum antibiotics or no improvement. Consult ID.
content.renal_dose: Adjust antibiotics for renal impairment (common with abscess).

timeout_checklist: Review culture results (blood, urine, abscess) and de-escalate
Ensure drainage performed if abscess >3-5cm or no improvement in 48-72h
Switch IV to PO after 2-4 weeks if improving and abscess drained
Repeat imaging at 2-4 weeks to assess abscess resolution
Ensure total duration is 4-6 weeks (prolonged therapy needed)
Discontinue vancomycin if no MRSA
content.iv_to_po_opportunities: Most patients can switch to PO after 2-4 weeks of IV therapy if afebrile, abscess drained/resolving, and pathogen susceptible to oral agent. Oral options: Ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, TMP-SMX, linezolid (MRSA).
content.source_control: Antibiotics alone have high failure rate (30-50%). Drainage is MANDATORY for most abscesses. Do NOT delay drainage if indicated.
content.follow_up_imaging: Repeat CT or ultrasound at 2-4 weeks to confirm abscess resolution. If not resolving, consider repeat drainage or surgical intervention.
